msgSnippet: ... Perhaps that depends on what you define as TDD. When faced with a large legacy code base with no tests, I will still write a test before introducing a new
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> Some of the situations I have encountered in the past and the present where
> TDD is not a practical choice are GUI or mobile developments (something I do
> a lot these days). I also work fairly regularly with very large code bases
> that have grown organically over several years, and again, practicing TDD at
> this level would cost a lot more than doing things traditionally.

Perhaps that depends on what you define as TDD. When faced with a large
legacy code base with no tests, I will still write a test before
introducing a new feature or fixing a bug. I may not try to achieve 90%
coverage on such code, but I do find TDD to be useful for almost any
problem I tackle.
